reviewText:
Preface: GSB filled a very unique niche for me, and I appreciate the original for what it is.  I have literally grown up with video games, and I am critical of them because they are important to me.  I like this franchise.  Keep that in mind.

GSB2 is immediately something of a letdown.  The first --UNQUESTIONABLE FIRST-- thing any sequel should ALWAYS be doing is refining its UI.  GSB suffered from a horribly primitive UI wherein the mouse hand performed 99% of the interaction.  Ten fingers plus only one point of input=a very inelegant interface.  A game with as many sliders, locations, and items to interact with on a constant basis as GSB absolutely DEMANDS a more fluid control scheme.

GSB2, above all else, has not remedied the problems of the first game.  Aside from the formation shortcut shift+F (the only one I use on an absolutely constant basis) there are far too many inputs and interactions in dire need of shortcut buttons, hotkeys and less intervening mouse clicks to get things done.  There are so many forced, unneeded clicks to jump around that just moving from one screen to the one you want feels tedious.  The series of actions needed to navigate the menu are unbelievably clunky; I counted having to hit the 'main menu' button FOUR TIMES CONSECUTIVELY to get to the actual main menu from some screens.  Not cool, Positech.  We're about to hit 2016; you can do better than this.

I highly recommend, indeed IMPLORE the devs to rethink the menu navigation and interface; there is no logical need for it to be this clunky.  Number crunchy though it may be, it's played by human beings, and needs to be designed for human hands.

That said, I do still appreciate this sequel for what it is; more ways to build and blast tons of spaceships.  New weapon types, new support systems, more classes of ships, BIGGER ships, and generally just MORE of everything to like about the original.  If we can just get some efficiency, some human consideration, better conveyance and some elegance in design, GSB could go from cult favorite to mega-hit very, VERY quickly.

There is a great deal of satisfaction though in seeing 3 or 4 heavy dreadnaughts glide through the debries of theri foes.\nNow, the mods. The first version had a healthy modding community and had tons of fun and crazy stuff. Battlestar Galactica, Star Wars, and Star Trek were mod favorites. There was also a ton of mod races that were fresh fromt the mind of their creators. The game was made for mods and it was part of its brilliance. I haven't tried playing around with modding this version yet, but if it is anything like the first game it is sure to get some amazing mods and great DLC expansions.

What I don't enjoy are the ship modules.  There's really only a few of them worth using and there are obvious bests and not really any strategy to making a good ship unless you run into a problem where there's an anomoly that prevents you from using one of the components you're using.  Multi warhead missiles is the only weapon you ever need which is ridiculous, a nuke if you feel like it, tons of armor, repairs, no shields are EVER needed and rarely useful.  You never really need engines either which is uh.. a bit unrealistic but whatever.  Engines shouldn't even be a module, they should just come on the ship. reviewText:
GSB2 improves upon nearly everything from GSB1.  If you're like me and you like watching some pew-pew and some boom-boom in space, you'll like Gratuitous Space Battles 2.  GSB2 is about the spectacle of watching fleets of spaceships blow each other up.  It is the best part of any sci-fi movie, turned into a game.

That being said, I will now qualify my recommendation and address complaints I've seen others make.  While I do think GSB2 improves upon nearly everything from GSB1, it doesn't really CHANGE a whole lot.  Nothing is really new or revolutionary to the design, although almost everything is a step up.  And the complaints others have made about about crashing, or what feels like a lack of content, are legitimate, although it has more content than GSB1.  Like I said, there isn't a lot of NEW stuff, although basically everything has been improved.

GSB2 is a much prettier game than 1, with better lighting, better looking explosions, better looking ships, customizable ship appearances, and better looking debris and backgrounds.  I did turn off asteroids because, while they look cool, they were ultimately distracting.  Because there are a lot more layers of things happening (debris, ships, asteroids, clouds, etc.) it can be difficult to understand the action at times, especially when you have the wreckage of dozens of ships slowly floating across your screen.  While everything has more detail, GSB1 looked cleaner, if that makes sense.

GSB2 seems more balanced than 1.  I'm writing this review after having played all the way through the missions that come with the game, and I beat them all on normal.  Combined arms are now much more important.  Whereas in GSB1 I basically never used destroyers, they have now become an important part of every fleet, because fighters are now harder to deploy.  Fighters in GSB1 were OP; you could deploy as many of them as you wanted, limited only by pilot availability, and simply use them to overwhelm larger and more powerful fleets.  Now fighters have fuel, which limits their deployment time before they have to refuel, and they have to be assigned to a carrier" (cruiser or dreadnought with appropriate module) and carriers have limited hangar space.  Overall I found fleet composition to be more challenging and thoughtful experience.

Even in the few hours I've played

2. The Crashes. Oh god, the crashes. My computer handles most games reasonably well, Fallout series (3 and Vegas) on Ultra etc. etc. yet even on low settings, GSB 2 keeps dying. I can only play the first two battlefields and even then only if I don't put too many units in. In larger scale engagements, the game will just crash mid-battle. Oh and if I lose (even on the small maps), the game freezes and I can't even use Task manager to shut it down. I have to log off from the Ctrl-Alt-Delete screen.

3. Virtually no racial distinction. They feel like slight variations of the same ships. In GSB 1, choosing a race made a significant difference to the way the game was played and yet in GSB 2, all that really matters is your choice of fitting. The hull itself, and by extension the race, makes almost no difference.

The only good feature at the moment is the visual customization... and that doesn't redeem the game. In its current state, for me at least, it's completely unplayable. For now I recommend not buying this game; it shouldn't have been released until it was ready.

reviewText:
Unlike many other reviewers of this game, I have not played the first installment of this series.  That being said, I will present what I like and dislike about this game alone with no comparisons between GSB1 and GSB2, which I believe is more fair and unbiased.

Pros:
+ Good and easy user interface, which is very easy to use and understand
+ Sound quality is surprisingly well done
+ Ship building mechanism is fun and also easy to use
+ Space battles are graphically impressive and fun to watch
+ Fun and challenging online community
+ Plenty of unlockables and a nice variety of missions to play through

Cons:
- The game is prone to crashing.  It is the single biggest annoyance I have with this game.
- The AI that commands your ships can't be controlled but you can set their target priorities before the battle.  Some people seem to dislike this but I think it works well in this game.
- I personally would enjoy more of a serious campaign that has some story, but this game does not have that.
- Fighters seem to be a bit overpowered in my opinion, as a few carriers with several wings of fighters can overwhelm almost anything including large capital ships.

The game is quite enjoyable if you like watching your creations destroy and get destroyed in large quantities.  While I think that the twenty dollar price tag is a bit steep for most people, this game is very much worth the money if you wait for it to go on sale.  I have certainly got my money's worth out of it.  *IF the development team can fix the crashing issue,  I believe this game is well worth owning for gamers who want a relaxing space battle game.  As I said before, I haven't played the first game in this series, but having said that, this game has loads of features that I enjoy and that I believe are well done.

reviewText:
So I came across a bug in GSB2.  I've noticed a few other minor ones before this, small graphics glitches, ship designs which temporarily disappeared, and such; But nothing which actually prevented me from playing.  Until this morning.

I was trying to beat one of the latter scenarios using only frigates or lighter ships.  A futile mission perhaps, but that's partly the appeal of the game.  Setting a goal and then trying to beat it with the absolute minimum expenditure of resources.  This lead to me creating a huge formation of frigates, which seems to have exceeded the maximum that the game would allow.  This caused the game to crash whenever I’d try to start the scenario.

I’ve been in this situation before. You submit a bug report and then maybe get a canned email response saying that the problem will be looked into, and then nothing further . You wait months and just hope that there will be a fix in the next patch.  Hell, you often just hope that there will BE a next patch.

So how long do you think it took Positech to get this resolved?  About 10 minutes. I got a personal response straight from Cliff (the one-man developer of GSB2), got a workaround to the problem and assurance that it’d be fixed in the next patch. That’s a huge indication that this is someone who really cares about their games and will work to make ‘em great.

Unfortunately this experience has left me in an existential crisis and has potentially revealed a serious flaw in my psychological makeup. Years of internet immersion has honed my sarcastic wit to razor sharp perfection.  I can be a snarky ♥♥♥-hole at the drop of a hat, spewing smarm and vitriol at anybody who dares to not be perfect on the internet, all from the comfort and anonymity of my bedroom.  And I like to think I’m quite a bit better at it than most.  But now I find that I need to praise something. To be positive and supportive. My every instinct recoils at the notion.

But why should it.  I really like the game. Judging from his lineup of games, Cliff seems to have very similar tastes to my own. Games that don’t rely on twitch skills, but on planning and strategy.  Games where you can constantly tweak a bunch of individual small aspects to see how they affect the system as a whole.

And that’s what GSB2 is. If you think that just completing each of the missions is the goal, you can achieve that fairly quickly and with little planning.  Just throw more ships at the problem and eventually you’ll win.  But the real challenge is trying to do it with as little as possible.  I usually start by making a fleet which can win the engagement fairly decisively, and then start whittling it down and tweaking stuff until I think I’ve got it down to the bare minimum. Eventually I get to where I’m sure it’s just not possible to do it with anything less.  Then I check the high scores and see that not only do I not have the best score ever, I’m about 50,000 points shy of it.  Holy ♥♥♥♥, I’ve got to rethink this whole strategy. This is how this game eats up hours of my life.  And it’s time well spent as far as I’m concerned.

reviewText:
Please kindly find my video review here:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dOJc6Z4VWT0

Game-play

Gratuitous Space Battles is back again, and this sequel is a dream come true to players who enjoyed the first game.
Being famous for its vast customization and allowing the players to exert their creativity, this time, even more customization is allowed.

Being able to color and re-size the vast amount of parts and modules to mount on different ship hulls sizes and more-specialized-hulls for the construction of your space-crafts, provided great complexity and possibilities for you to spend hours just to construct your own unique ship.
With mods being available and sharing of spacecraft design through steam, there is no limit to the content of this game.

This game features the standard mission game mode, which the player will need to defeat a group of preset enemy space-crafts. The less total cost of your space-crafts deployed to tackle the mission, the more honor points you will get in-return for you to unlock more modules, equipment and factions. Again, there is no direct control over the ships during the battle. However, you can assign certain tasks and behaviors of your ships during the deployment phase.
There is also an online mode of the game, which you can tackle space-craft formations created by other players.

However, this sequel still fall short on one major problem inherited from the previous game. That is, the lack of a background story. Without a story-line to hold the game together, this game ultimately feels like a space battle simulator like the one in Ender’s Game.

Presentation

Visually speaking, the upgrade of graphics was not dramatic, but there are definitely more efforts put into the details of the space-crafts and the battlefield.
Lighting and shadow effects were also improved to help create a more realistic 2.5 dimensional environment than its predecessor.

Being able to build your dream ship is one thing, but the greatest enjoyment comes from the way it shines in action or…in total destruction.
There was also a great improvement on the user interface during the battle and players can now look at each space-craft’s status at the same time.
Although some of the icons might be a bit too large which could block the view of the battlefield, this was no doubt a welcoming improvement.

Summary

In summary, if you are interested in the previous game or being a Sci-Fi fan, there is no doubt that you will be spending hours and hours of time in this sequel.
For those that are new, it depends on whether you would value the limitless creation provided by this game over the lack of a background story.

edit: after the changes the dev team have made/ are making i am changing this review into a recommended one. It is definitely worth the money now since the patches (which were changes to research and extra levels etc.) i will be spending more time with this game in the near future, because it is really fun and strategic, the art style is awesome and i love the customization. On release day i felt there as little to no reason to edit ships, since normal mode was too easy (for me anyway being familiar with the previous game), but the recent changes give me motivation to spend more time tinkering and figuring out how deep the game really is. I look forward to the future of this game, mod support, dlc etc, have me excited to play more, my only big wish is if somehow there could be a feature to fight randomly generated fleets for more honor, but there'd need to be more stuff to unlock with honor to keep you going in the long run! thank you!

reviewText: Personally, I found this superior (see footnote) game to be unmistakably flawed in enough areas to make me not want to invest near the time I spent in Gratuitous Space Battles. (time & enjoyment vs cost) Which in the end makes this a title to avoid.\n\nFootnote: The developer believes this game is superior in every aspect to the original, but since it didn't make him more money than your average $13 USD per hour worker, he doesn't want to update it anymore. I can't say I blame him, no amount of bugfixes is going to fix the real problem with this one. But seeing as the customers who tend to buy and play games make about that much per hour, I'm left wondering if I'm supporting the right person. I hope his next game returns to the quality I came to expect from his other titles.
